## Stanisław Lem's Life Journey and Intellectual Development

Stanisław Lem was born in 1921 in Lwów (now Lviv, Ukraine), where he spent his childhood. In 1945, after Lwów was annexed into Soviet Ukraine, the family, along with many other Polish citizens, was resettled to Kraków, where Lem, at his father's insistence, took up medical studies at the Jagiellonian University.

## The Crucial Role of Mieczysław Choynowski

In 1948-50 Lem worked in the Jagiellonian University as an assistant of Mieczysław Choynowski, defined by Lem as his "Intellectual mentor". Between 1948 and 1950 Lem worked as a junior research assistant at the Konserwatorium Naukoznawcze (The Circle for the Science of Science) lead by doctor Mieczyslaw Choynowski.

In Kraków he showed his "Theory of Brain Functions" to Dr. Mieczysław Choynowski – a philosopher and friend of Witkacy. Choynowski was not, to put it delicately, impressed with this work, but employed the guest at the Conservatory of Science he had founded, and then entrusted him with writing press reviews for "Życie Nauki".

## Intellectual Circles and Cybernetics

Choynowski guided Lem towards science, so he started to study Cybernetics of Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine by N. Wiener and A Mathematical Theory of Communication by C.F Shannon, among other works. The Western scientific works brought by Choynowski were an invaluable source for young Lem – dictionary in hand, he struggled through the works of cybernetics creator Norbert Wiener.

He got a job as a scientific research assistant at Jagiellonian University, where he taught courses and reviewed scientific publications for a journal called The Life of Science. He also became interested in cybernetics and taught himself English by reading the work of mathematician Norbert Wiener.

The discussions held in the circle of Conservatory participants gave rise to the "Dialogues" published in 1957. Referencing the famous work of Bishop Berkeley, the "Dialogues" contain, in addition to considerations on the prospects of cybernetics, also a critical analysis of the prevailing political system.

## Lem's Relationship with Lwów

Throughout the entirety of his life, Stanisław Lem remained deeply attached to his original hometown of Lwów and missed it greatly. Although he never called for Poland to retake the city, he expressed sorrow and felt a sense of injustice at Poland losing the city to the USSR after the Second World War. Stanisław Lem would never see his beloved hometown again. He consciously renounced such a possibility.

## Legacy and Recognition

The writer received several Polish and international awards for literature, decorations and honorary degrees (Warsaw Polytechnic, Opole University, University of Lvov, Jagiellonian University). Stanisław Lem died from heart failure in the hospital of the Jagiellonian University Medical College, Kraków on 27 March 2006 at the age of 84.

The search reveals how the intellectual circles around Choynowski at Jagiellonian University in Kraków became crucial for Lem's development as both a science fiction writer and futurologist, introducing him to cybernetics and Western scientific thought that would profoundly influence his literary work.
